{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3689964,"name":"Murilo Miranda Santos","username":"murilo404","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/m/49beb7/{size}.png","created_at":"2025-07-25T18:12:07.200Z","cooked":"

Good morning everyone! My FRC team recently purchased addressable LED strips to install in our elevator. We want to program them with the Arduino UNO. However, we’re unsure how to electrically connect the Arduino to the PDP. We’re also unsure whether the Arduino is sufficient or whether we should implement something in Java. Thank you for your help!

","post_number":1,"post_type":1,"posts_count":4,"updated_at":"2025-07-25T18:12:07.200Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":10,"reads":112,"readers_count":111,"score":72.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":504645,"topic_slug":"how-to-connect-addressable-led-strips","display_username":"Murilo Miranda Santos","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":69705,"hidden":false,"trust_level":1,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/how-to-connect-addressable-led-strips/504645/1","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null,"can_vote":false},{"id":3689973,"name":"Matthew L","username":"Another_Person1","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/a/a87d85/{size}.png","created_at":"2025-07-25T18:21:47.038Z","cooked":"

You can connect one set of addressable leds to the roborio PWM ports and control it from Java, to simplify things.

Otherwise, you could probably connect the Uno directly to the PDP through the barrel jack or the VIN pin. Just be aware about how many LEDs you are using, as there are memory and power limits, and add a 300-500 ohm resistor on the data line connecting to the Uno and a 500-1000uf capacitor to avoid voltage spikes and glitching.

There are several ways to do it. You can use the arduino with power straight to the GPIO or usb/barrel with a 5v DC-DC converter or there is an AddressableLED class that can be used on the rio. Here is the WPI LED doc and this is my unfinished but functional implementation of LEDs using it. Also heres a doc on powering the UNO.

Gur | Electronics & Software mentor","username":"YuvalGur-2231","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/y/df788c/{size}.png","created_at":"2025-07-25T20:49:16.275Z","cooked":"

What LED type you use?

The WS2812 / WS2812b
Need 5V of power, which can be reached by using a VRM or a non-FRC 12DC to 5DC converter. Take note of the fact that each LED will require typicly ~20mA so from the VRM you can get max of about 100 LED strip.

We use the WS2815 LED which requires 12V so no need for VRM or any special converter. We connect it to a 10A fuse in the MPM - and never get even near the full current capacity.

We program it via the PWM ports on the RIO (with the known fpga code) but have seen some performance issues regarding it unless we specifically regulate our access frequency. So using an Arduino might be a smart attempt - do update on how it worked for you!
